prompt: Facts: Date of Incident: 27.07.1995, around 7:30 PM.; Location: Village Sakhauti, P.S. Daurala, District Meerut, Uttar Pradesh.; Victim: Prem Singh.; Accused: Naresh, Mahesh, Surender, Sukhbir, Ompal, Jagmer, and Balbir.; Sequence of Events: Prem Singh was returning home from his fields when he was attacked near the house of Rakesh by the accused persons.; Alleged Weapons: Lathis, Tabal (a sharp-edged weapon/axe), Spear.; FIR: Lodged by Balbir Singh (PW-1, brother of the deceased) on 27.07.1995 at 9:00 PM at P.S. Daurala (approx. 5 km from the village) against all 7 accused.; IPC Sections in FIR: Sections 147, 148, 149, 302 IPC.; Key Witnesses: Balbir Singh (PW-1, informant, brother), Tejbir Singh (PW-2, son), Om Wati (PW-3, wife). All claimed to have witnessed the incident.; Medical Evidence: Post-mortem conducted by Dr. Naresh Kumar Sharma (PW-4) on 28.07.1995. Findings included multiple ante-mortem injuries: 5 incised wounds (attributed to sharp-edged weapons like Tabal/Spear), 6 contusions, and abrasions (attributed to lathis/blunt weapons). Cause of death: Shock and haemorrhage due to ante-mortem injuries.; Investigation: IO (PW-5) visited the spot, prepared site plan, recovered blood-stained earth, recorded witness statements.; Trial Court Judgment (15.02.1999): Acquitted all accused. Reasons cited: PW-1, PW-2, PW-3 were related and interested witnesses; contradictions in their testimonies regarding specific weapons used by specific accused and sequence of events; delay in FIR copy reaching the Magistrate (sent on 28.07.1995, received on 29.07.1995); non-examination of independent witnesses named in the FIR; motive (minor previous altercation) deemed insufficient.; High Court Judgment: Allowed the State's appeal against acquittal. Convicted Naresh, Mahesh, Surender, Sukhbir, Ompal, and Jagmer under Section 302 read with Section 149 IPC (Life Imprisonment) and Section 148 IPC (1 year RI). Accused Balbir was acquitted by the High Court. HC found trial court's reasons for acquittal flimsy and perverse, held testimonies of PW-1, PW-2, PW-3 credible and corroborated by medical evidence.; Supreme Court Appeal: Filed by the six convicted accused against the High Court judgment. | IPC: Section 147 (Rioting), Section 148 (Rioting, armed with deadly weapon), Section 149 (Unlawful assembly - vicarious liability), Section 300 (Murder definition), Section 302 (Punishment for Murder)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court correctly reversed the perverse acquittal by the Trial Court, which ignored credible evidence and focused on minor discrepancies.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415", "State of Rajasthan v. Sohan Lal (2004) 5 SCC 573", "Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor AIR 1934 PC 227"]}, {"argument": "The ocular testimonies of PW-1, PW-2, and PW-3 (related witnesses) are consistent, credible, natural, and fully corroborated by the medical evidence (PW-4).", "precedents": ["Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1953 SC 364", "State of U.P. v. Samman Dass (1972) 3 SCC 201", "Allarakha K. Mansuri v. State of Gujarat (2002) 3 SCC 57", "Sachchey Lal Tiwari v. State of U.P. (2004) 11 SCC 410"]}, {"argument": "The formation of an unlawful assembly with the common object of murdering Prem Singh is proven by the number of accused, the deadly weapons carried, the manner of assault, and the nature/number of injuries inflicted.", "precedents": ["Masalti v. State of U.P. AIR 1965 SC 202", "Lalji v. State of U.P. (1989) 1 SCC 437", "Roy Fernandes v. State of Goa (2012) 3 SCC 221", "Mizaji v. State of U.P. AIR 1959 SC 572"]}, {"argument": "Minor discrepancies or inconsistencies in witness statements do not affect the core credibility of the prosecution case, especially when corroborated by medical evidence.", "precedents": ["State of Punjab v. Karnail Singh (2003) 11 SCC 271", "Leela Ram v. State of Haryana (1999) 9 SCC 525", "Rammi alias Rameshwar v. State of M.P. (1999) 8 SCC 649"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The High Court exceeded its jurisdiction by reversing a well-reasoned acquittal merely because another view was possible. The Trial Court's assessment of evidence was plausible.", "precedents": ["Murugesan v. State Through Inspector of Police (2012) 10 SCC 383", "Tota Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1987 SC 1083", "Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154"]}, {"argument": "The testimonies of PW-1, PW-2, and PW-3 are unreliable as they are close relatives of the deceased (interested witnesses) and their statements contain material contradictions and improvements over initial versions.", "precedents": ["State of Rajasthan v. Kalki (1981) 2 SCC 752", "Harbeer Singh v. Sheeshpal Singh (2016) 16 SCC 418", "Kali Ram v. State of Himachal Pradesh (1973) 2 SCC 808"]}, {"argument": "The unexplained delay in the FIR copy reaching the Magistrate casts serious doubt on the authenticity and timing of the FIR, suggesting potential deliberation and concoction.", "precedents": ["Thulia Kali v. State of Tamil Nadu (1972) 3 SCC 393", "Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra (1978) 4 SCC 371", "Arjun Marik v. State of Bihar 1994 Supp (2) SCC 372"]}, {"argument": "The prosecution failed to establish a strong motive for such a heinous crime allegedly committed by seven individuals.", "precedents": ["State of U.P. v. Kishanpal (2008) 16 SCC 73 (Motive less important if direct evidence credible)", "Nathuni Yadav v. State of Bihar (1998) 9 SCC 238 (Absence of motive can be relevant when evidence is doubtful)", "Bipin Kumar Mondal v. State of West Bengal (2010) 12 SCC 91 (Motive is a circumstance but not indispensable)"]}]}
